div1.p: Reed discusses her beloved father's letters and her lengthy illness.

div1.head: Letter from Blossom [Emile M. Reed] to Philip Showalter Hench, May 8, 1943
div1.opener:
Saturday -
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
Dear Dr - Hench -
div1.p:
This is like a
voice from the dead
isn't it? All during my
last illness, I often thought
of my promise to send
you one or two of my
beloved father's letters! now
here they are and for
you! Dont give them
away, please - In his
early days, his letters to
mother were so sweet
I am adding one to those
along with the ones
of yellow fever. Last Summer
I tried to do one gardener's
work & landed in the
hospital & for 8 months!
The great mistake was
letting no one write or
see me & keeping me
behind bars! Next time
you learn of that, please
come & get me! All strange
doctors & some very brisque
I'm telling you - finally
my good friend, Dr. Stanley's
widow took me to her
home & I got fine and
am very well now -
I think, my family were
very much afraid of
me - me of all people!
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
How is Mrs. Hench &
did I understand my
family to say you
had a new baby?
Do write me some
news of you. Mother
is quite well for 87
years & we are at
the cottage. It gave
me great pleasure to
go over father's letters. I
I have tried to send
ones. I thought you like
best. Our best wishes
to you & Mrs. Hench -
